Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Photocatalysis, Photoconversion, and Photoelectrochemistry: Fundamentals, Techniques, and Applications for the 21st Century
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Malcolm D. E. Forbes of Bowling Green State University is supported by the Chemical Catalysis program, Division of Chemistry, the Americas program, Office of International Science and Engineering, and the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems Division to organize an international workshop entitled "Workshop: Photocatalysis, Photoconversion, and Photoelectrochemistry: Fundamentals, Techniques, and Applications for the 21st Century." The workshop will be held on May 22-23, 2016 on the campus of the Universidad Andre√¨s Bello in Santiago, Chile, immediately preceding the 25th Meeting of the Inter-American Photochemical Society in Santiago, Chile. Fifteen early-career U.S. student and post-doctoral researchers of diverse background meet with 10 students from different South and Central American countries and jointly interact with senior US and South American faculty in a constructive environment.

The aim of this workshop award is to encourage international collaboration and to provide the US students and postdoctoral researchers with an international experience. The workshop exposes them to the current frontiers and future directions in fundamental and applied research in photocatalysis. The workshop serves to provide much needed cross-fertilization, and bonds are formed between US and South American participants that could potentially last a scientific lifetime. Furthermore, the US participants develop a broader perspective on international science at an early stage in their careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On May 21-23, 2016, a workshop took place in Santiago, Chile, called Photocatalysis, Photoconversion, and Photoelectrochemistry Fundamentals, Techniques, and Applications for the 21st Century. The workshop was funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the NSF Chemsitry Division. The co–Chairs of the workshop were Professor Malcolm Forbes of Bowling Green State University and Dra. Nancy Pizarro of the Universidad Andrés Bello. 

More than 45 scientists participated in the workshop, with all 19 presentations given by students and postdoctoral researchers. The presentations were outstanding in every regard, and included four from South American students.

Intellectual Merit: The program included sessions on environmental and biological photocatalysis, comparisons of nano–, supramolecular, and polymer composite architectures. Additional discussions included the remediation of carbon dioxide, hydrogen production, and the development of biomimetic catalysts for nitrogen fixation. These are all considered to be cutting edge topics in modern photocatalysis, and the talks led to many interesting discussions about future developments in the field, especially in regard to titanium dioxide chemistry (charge injection, interface characterization, etc.).

Broader Impacts: This workshop was a departure from the norm in that all of the talks were given by the junior researchers, while the faculty members and more senior scientists drove the discussion.  This provided an excellent training opportunity for the younger scientists, some of whom had never given a public lecture before. In addition, the talks were not just a collection of their own research results: the students and postdocs had to learn something outside their own research topic.  Many of them found this challenging at first, but to help guide them, they were each assigned a research mentor (who was not their advisor). The mentoring process proved highly effective in producing the highest quality presentations. In addition, the U.S. students funded by the NSF to travel to Chile got exposure to science in a foreign country (it was the first trip to South America for all of them).

Outcomes: The workshop produced very interesting and high level dicussions about the present status and future directions of photocatalysis in the broadest sense. Many of the students involved commented that their experience at the workshop had improved their perspective on their own research projects, and two students maintained that they were reinvigorated by the workshop, gaining the motivation and enthusiasm for completion of their PhD degrees. Many of the senior scientists gave high praise to the students for the quality of their presentations and their poise under pressure in front of a very knowledgable audience. The workshop gave many scientists new ideas and fueled discussion of new experiments and collaborations.
